title: Exercise Northstar: D-30
description: A major military exercise kicks off in 30 days. Command wants a live screen showing where every unit is, how many supplies they have, and whether their radios are working. Your team builds it from scratch.
storyContext: Your team just got seconded to a classified project. In 30 days, the SAF kicks off Exercise Northstar, the biggest multi-domain exercise this decade. Command wants a single screen that shows every unit's position, supply levels, and comms status in real time. The catch: it has to work in a jungle training area with barely any mobile signal. You have one month to build something that generals will trust with live operational decisions.

software-engineer.title: Architect the Dashboard Components
software-engineer.instruction: The commanders need a single-screen dashboard. You are designing which data component feeds into which rendering slot based on resource intensity and real-time data dependencies. The main display needs the most resource-intensive component. Side panels handle supporting feeds. The status bar shows lightweight system health. Drag each component to the right slot.
software-engineer.hint: The most important information (the one commanders look at every few seconds) should take up the most space.

data-scientist.title: Choose How to Handle the Data Flow
data-scientist.instruction: Field units send their position every 30 seconds from tablets and GPS devices. That's thousands of location updates per minute flowing into the system. How do you process all that into useful information on the screen?
data-scientist.hint: When data arrives constantly, handle it as it arrives, but ask yourself how much instant accuracy you really need versus a few seconds of delay.

options.label: Process every location update the instant it arrives. The screen updates in real time but needs heavy computing power, and one bad reading could glitch the whole display.
Group updates every 5 seconds and clean the data before showing it. Commanders see positions that are at most 5 seconds old and the screen never shows bad data.
Process data on the unit's own device and only send a summary. Cuts radio bandwidth by 80%, which matters in the field, but you lose the detailed raw readings.
Send critical alerts in real time but batch everything else every 10 seconds. Balanced, but more complex to build and maintain.

cloud-engineer.title: Set Up the Field Network
cloud-engineer.instruction: The exercise happens in a training area with patchy mobile signal. You need to set up a reliable network linking field units to the command screen. Put the setup steps in the right order.
cloud-engineer.hint: You can't build a reliable network if you don't know where the problems are. Test thoroughly before the exercise starts.

items.label: Walk the training ground to find areas with no signal and note any obstacles
Set up portable network relay nodes at key positions across the area
Configure a satellite uplink as a backup for when mobile signal drops completely
Test data speeds from the furthest unit position back to the command post
Set up automatic switching so devices seamlessly jump to the best available network
